coredata.dc:title: Kinetics of ethylidyne formation on Pt(111) From time-dependent infrared spectroscopy
coredata.dc:creator: Mohsin, Sheher B.
Trenary, Michael
Robota, Heinz J.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We have measured the rate of formation of ethylidyne on Pt(111) by monitoring the intensity increase of the symmetric CH3 bend at 1339 cm−1 as a function of time between 230 and 250 K. We obtain a first-order rate constant with an activation energy of 14±1 kcal/mol for a 0.3 L ethylene exposure at 100 K.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS tO February 1989 Volume 154, number 6 KINETICS OF ETHYLIDYNE FORMATION ON Pt(lI1) FROM TIME-DEPENDENT INFRARED SPECTROSCOPY Sheher B, MOHSIN, Michael TRENARY Department of Chemistry. University of Illinois at Chicago, Chicago, IL 60680. USA and Heinz J. ROBOTA Allied-Signal Engineered Materials Research Center, 50 EastAlgonquin Road, Box 5016, Des Flames. IL 60017. USA Received 19 September 1988; in final form 18 November 1988 We have measured the rate of formation of ethylidyne on Pt (lit) by monitoring she intensity increase of she symmetric Cit3 bend at 1339 em~ as a function of time between 230 and 250 K. We obtain a first-order rate constant with an activation energy of 14 1 keal/mol for a 0.3 L ethylene exposure at 100 K. The mechanism of chemical reactions at the gas solid interface involve three basic steps: (1) adsorp- tion of reactants from the gas phase; (2) molecular transformations on the surface; (3) desorption of the products. Most surface chemical kinetics studies have focused on steps (1) and (3). Yet step (2), which includes reactions between adsofbed species as well as unimolecular reactions, is often the key step of the overall surface chemical reaction. Studies of molec- ular transformations on surfaces require a technique which can readily distinguish between different spe- cies while they are adsorbed and which can monitor their coverages as a function of time. Techniques which have been used for this purpose include sec- ondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) and time-re- solved electron energy loss spectroscopy (TREELS). With SIMS, one monitors the ion fragments pro- duced by bombarding the adsorbate-covered surface with noble gas ions. From the identity of the ion fragments one can infer the identity of adsorbed spe- cies. The variation of SIMS intensity with time is presumably due to the variation in surface concen- tration with time, The disadvantages of this tech- nique are that it is destructive and that the relation- ship between the ion fragments observed and the coverage of a particular surface species is often am- biguous. Vibrational spectroseopy has the advantage that it is nondestructive and that a given vibrational band is very specific to a particular surface species. The two most widely used techniques for surface vi- brational spectroscopy are infrared reflection ab- sorption spectroscopy (IRAS) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS). Time-resolved EELS has been successfully used in a number of recent surface studies [1]. More recently FT-IRAS has been shown to yield spectra of the C 0 stretch fast enough to fol- low changes in CO coverage as a function of time [2 6]. In a dispersive JR study of the kinetics of CH3COOH decomposition on Ni( 100), Scharpf and Benziger [71 followed the IR peaks associated with the symmetric and asymmetric O C O stretches as a function of time. In this paper we demonstrate that surface kinetic studies with Ff-IRAS are not limited to the intense vibrational bands associated with car- bon oxygen bonds, but can also be used to follow the kinetics of a surface reaction involving only carbon and hydrogen atoms. The technique should therefore be applicable to a large variety of surface reactions relevant to heterogeneous catalysis. The adsorption of ethylene on metal surfaces has been studied extensively [81. It is well known that ethylene is molecularly adsorbed in a di-a-bonded 0 009-2614/89/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B,V (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 511 Volume 154, nttmber6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 February 1989 configuration on Pt (ill) at temperatures below 200 K and that upon heating to ~ 280 K, it rearranges with loss of a hydrogen atom, to a stable species which has been characterized as ethylidyne (~ CCI-13). This species is known to have a C5~ structure with the C C axis perpendicular to the surface [9]. The vi- brational spectrum for this species has been well studied [9,10]. Ethylidyne is characterized by bands at 1118, 1339 and 2884 cm which are due to the C C stretch, CH3 symmetric bend, and C H stretch respectively. The band at 1339 cm~, which is due to the symmetric CH3 bending mode, is the most in- tense band in the spectrum. This band is much more intense than any of the bands of di-a-bonded eth- ylene. It is also spectrally isolated and thus provides a convenient monitor of the surface concentration of ethylidyne. The kinetics of this surface reaction has been previously studied with SIMS and 1-12 TDP [11 and very recently with transient near edge X-ray ab- sorption fine structure (T-NEXAFS) [12]. The apparatus consists of a stainless steel ultra- high vacuum chamber with a base pressure of 8>< lO~ Torr (based on an ion gauge calibrated for N2) coupled to a dedicated commercial VFJR spec- trometer (Cygnus 25, Mattson Instruments). The p- polarized IR beam enters and exits the UHV cham- ber through differentially pumped viton 0-ring sealed KBr windows. Other techniques included in our ap- paratus are Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), low energy electron diffraction (LEED) and mass spec- trometry with a quadrupole analyzer. A more com- plete description of the apparatus is contained in an earlier publication [13]. The preparation of the Pt( 111) crystal has been described earlier [9]. The crystal is a 1 mm thick, 14 mm diameter disk attached to a liquid nitrogen res- ervoir by two 0.75 mm diameter tungsten Wires spot- welded to the sides of the crystal. The crystal was heated resistively by passing current through the tungsten wires. The crystal temperature was mea- sured with a chromel alumel thermocouple. A LEED pattern characteristic of a clean, wefl ordered Pt( 111) surface has been observed repeatedly. The crystal was judged to be clean if no impurities were detected with Auger spectroscopy. The most frequently observed contaminant was carbon. The procedure for carbon removal consisted of exposing the crystal at 700 K to 2x l0-~ Ton of 02 from a gas doser for 1 h. The crystal was briefly annealed to 1000 K before and after each 02 treatment. The procedure for kinetic studies was as follows: The clean crystal was exposed to ethylene by backfilling the chamber while the crystal temperature was held at 100 K. It was rapidly heated to the temperature at which the rate of ethy- lidyne formation was to be measured (230 250 K) The total time taken to reach this temperature was usually about 2 mm. The crystal was held at this tem- perature while a series of lR spectra were recorded as a function of time. The crystal temperature could be held constant to within 0.2 K. Fig. I shows the increase in intensity of the 1339 cm1 band as a function of time at several temper- atures following a 3 L exposure. The spectra were ob- tained with 2 cm resolution and represent an av- erage of 256 scans (74 s scanning time). Although a resolution lower than 2 cm~ could have been used for these studies, the small intrinsic full width of 1.8 cm for this band at these temperatures [9] leads to a greater peak height at higher resolutions. Ethyl- idyne formation rates at several temperatures were obtained by monitoring the intensity, in absorbance units, of this peak with time (fig. 2). We assume that the intensity is proportional to ethylidyne coverage. If we denote the absorbance of the ethylidyne peak at time t by A (I) and its value when the reaction is complete by A(oo), then A(co) A(t) is propor- tional to the ethylene coverage since each ethylene molecule is converted to an ethylidyne molecule. This J4fl~A J\~ 1320 t340 1361) 1320 1340 1304 1320 *340 1360 Wavenumber (un~) Fig. 1. The symmetric CH3 bend at 1339 em as a function of time after first exposing the crystal to 3 L of ethylene at 100 K then rapidly heating the crystal to the indicated temperatures. Temp (K) 233 2 U 41 Cl) ~ 512 volume 154, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 10 February 1989 assumes that there is no desorption of excess ethyl- ene, which is not the case at higher coverages as dis- cussed below. One method of obtaining values for k and A (on) was through a nonlinear least-squares fit ofthe experimentalA(t) to A(co)[l exp( kt)]. The value of k obtained was in good agreement with that obtained from the slopes in fig. 2, which shows plots of ln[l A(t)/A(oo)] as a function of time. The value of A(cc) was in good agreement with the value of A (cc) determined from spectra obtained after warming the crystal to room temperature. The linearity of the plots in fig. 2 is an indication that the reaction is first order in ethylene coverage. Note that this analysis is invalid for long times where A(l) cA(oo). For this reason we include only points for short enough times so that the rate constant de- termined is characteristic of the initial rate. Thus the range of times used for fig. 2 is less than in fig. 1. Results similar to those of figs. 1 and 2 were also ob- tained for the 0.3 L exposure although with a cor- responding reduction in signal level. We assumed IR peak heights were proportional to ethylidyne coverage. It is known that dipole dipole coupling between adsorbate vibrations can give non- linear intensity versus coverage [2]. However in a separate publication, we have shown that there are only small shifts in frequency with coverage indi- cating very little coupling between cthylidyne mol- ecules [14]. Also, the peak height would not be pro- portional to coverage if the peak width depended on coverage. However, we [14] have found that for ethylidyne on Pt( 111) the width is not sensitive to coverage. With the assumption of a linear depen- dence of peak height on coverage, we conclude that for exposures at 100 K, 0.3 L yields 60% of the ethyl- idyne coverage obtained with the 3 L exposure of ethylene. The 3 L exposure at 100 K in turn results in a coverage that is only 70% of the saturation cov- erage obtained by a 3 L exposure at 350 K. The sat- uration coverage of ethylidyne on Pt (111) has not been definitively established; it is either 0.25 or 0.5 monolayer (see ref. [9], and references therein). In an earlier publication [8] we have found that the in- trinsic width of the 1339 cm_t does depend on tem- perature; however, since the present measurements were made with 2 cm - instrumental resolution, the observed bandwidth here is only slightly tempera- ture dependent as is dominated by the instrumental linewidth. Fig. 3 shows the Arrhenius plot of In k versus 1/T for the rate constants of fig. 2. The slope gives an activation barrier of 18 1 kcal/mol and a pre- exponential of 10 ~ s~ for the 3 L exposure. The 0.3 L exposure yields an activation energy of 14 1 kcal/mol and a pre-exponential of lOb0TnI s~. A 0.1 L exposure yields an activation energy of 13 2 kcal/ mol and a pre-exponential of 108 2 s . The value of A (cc) for the 0.1 L exposure was 35% of the value obtained after a 0.3 L exposure. These values are close to those obtained with other techniques [11,12]. A number of elementary steps are involved in the conversion of di-a-bonded ethylene to ethylidyne. A hydrogen atom is transferred from one carbon atom .5 Ic C o 230 K 235 K + 241 K 245 K a 250 K o 1000 2000 3000 Time (Sceunds) Fig. 2. Plots of In [1 A (t)/A (x) I of the infrared peak heights (in absorbance units, A) as a function of time at various temper- atures. The linearity of the plots indicates that the reaction is first order in ethylene. The lines were obtained from a least-squares fit using only the data points shown. I 0 -6 .7 -8 -9, Qa~t~~tKcamoIe t8 1 Kcallmole no.3 L 3L 3.9) 4.0) 4.11 4.2) 4.31 4.4t I000IT Fig. 3. Plot of the In of the rate constants versus l/T for both the 3 and 0.3 L exposures. The slopes give activation energies of 18 (3 L) and 14 keal/mol (0.3 L) while the intercepts give pre-ex- ponentialsoflO3t (3L) and t0 ~ s (0.3L). 513 Volume 154, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEYITERS 10 February 1989 to the other, either directly or by way of the surface. A second hydrogen atom must be transferred from the carbon atom closest to the surface and a surface hydrogen bond must be formed. The carbon carbon bond must reorient from parallel to perpendicular to the surface. Whether these steps occur sequentially or in a single concerted step is, of course, quite dif- ficult to determine experimentally. However, molec- ular orbital calculations of ethylene on small plati- num clusters have been carried out which can provide insights into the energetics of various possible spe- cies. For example, the calculations of Kang and Anderson [15] indicate that vinylidene, CCH2, is an intermediate in the formation of ethylidyne from ethylene. Zaera [16] has recently proposed the vinyl species, CH=CH2, as the intermediate in etbylidyne formation. It is possible that the ethylidyne formation rate is related to the desorption rate of excess ethylene from the surface. Our thermal desorption results show that a 3 L exposure of ethylene at 100 K leads to molec- ular desorption of ethylene with a peak maximum at 275 K, in addition to the formation of ethylidyne. The coverage of the resulting ethylidyne, as indi- cated by the infrared intensities, is 30% less than the saturation coverage obtained by exposure at tem- peratures from 300 to 350 K. It is thus clear that the ethylene does not simply desorb because all available sites for ethylidyne formation are occu- pied. We have analyzed our ethylene thermal de- sorption results in various ways. From the heating rate of 2 K/s and an assumption of a pre-exponential of ~ s- we obtain an activation energy of de- sorption of 18 kcal/mol, which is in good agreement with Windham et al, [17], who obtained a value of 17 kcal/mol with the assumption of lO r for the pre-exponential. Various schemes for obtaining both the pre-exponential and activation energy from a single desorption trace have been proposed [18,19]. From the method of Tronconi and Lietti [18] we obtain v=5x lOtt s and Ed=lS.7 keal/mol while from the method of Chan et al. [19] we obtain v=8x 10 s and E~= 14.7 kcal/mol. The fact that a saturation coverage of ethylidyne is not obtained by the 3 L exposure at 100 K even though there is excess ethylene on the surface as indicated by the de- sorption of ethylene, indicates that the presence of ethylene on the surface can actually inhibit the for- mation of ethylidyne. Since the rate constant for ethylidyne formation is so close to the rate constant for ethylene desorption, this suggests that the rate limiting step for ethylidyne formation after a 3 L ex- posure at 100 K is the desorption of excess ethylene. This is supported by the fact that a lower exposure of 0.3 L at 100 K yields an activation energy of 14 kcal/mol and a pre-exponential of 1010 t s while a 0.1 L exposure yields values which are the same, within the experimental uncertainty, to the 0.3 L ex- posure. For the 0.3 and 0.1 L exposures we do not observe an ethylene desorption peak. Because heat- ing the crystal which has been exposed to 3 L of eth- ylene results in the desorption of ethylene as well as the formation of ethylidyne, our assumption that the IR signal from ethylidyne, in the form of A(oc) A(t), is proportional to the ethylene cov- erage may not be valid. Our results for the 0.3 and 0.1 L exposures do not suffer from this possible com- plication. Further insight into the coverage depen- dence of the kinetics of ethylidyne formation will re- quire further experiments at lower coverages. The use of FT-IRAS for this purpose will require improve- ments in sensitivity as we found that coverages lower than those corresponding to a 0.1 L exposure gave inadequate signal levels. Until such improvements occur, a more sensitive technique such as SIMS could be used to investigate the very low coverage kinetics. Such studies will be necessary to separate the intrin- sic formation rate for an isolated ethylidyne from the influence of lateral interactions. This work was supported in part by a gift from the Allied-Signal Engineered Materials Research Center and by a grant from the National Science Founda- tion. The authors thank Professor C.T. head.ce:title: Kinetics of ethylidyne formation on Pt(111) From time-dependent infrared spectroscopy

Allied-Signal Engineered Materials Research Center, 50 East Algonquin Road, Box 5016, Des Plaines, IL 60017, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We have measured the rate of formation of ethylidyne on Pt(111) by monitoring the intensity increase of the symmetric CH3 bend at 1339 cm−1 as a function of time between 230 and 250 K. We obtain a first-order rate constant with an activation energy of 14±1 kcal/mol for a 0.3 L ethylene exposure at 100 K.
